title: Graceful coloring is computationally hard
authors: Cyriac Antony, Laavanya D. and Devi Yamini S
abstract:
Given a (proper) vertex coloring $f$ of a graph $G$, say $f\colon V(G)\to
\mathbb{N}$, the difference edge labelling induced by $f$ is a function
$h\colon E(G)\to \mathbb{N}$ defined as $h(uv)=|f(u)-f(v)|$ for every edge $uv$
of $G$. A graceful coloring of $G$ is a vertex coloring $f$ of $G$ such that
the difference edge labelling $h$ induced by $f$ is a (proper) edge coloring of
$G$. A graceful coloring with range $\{1,2,\dots,k\}$ is called a graceful
$k$-coloring. The least integer $k$ such that $G$ admits a graceful
$k$-coloring is called the graceful chromatic number of $G$, denoted by
$\chi_g(G)$.
  We prove that $\chi(G^2)\leq \chi_g(G)\leq a(\chi(G^2))$ for every graph $G$,
where $a(n)$ denotes the $n$th term of the integer sequence A065825 in OEIS. We
also prove that graceful coloring problem is NP-hard for planar bipartite
graphs, regular graphs and 2-degenerate graphs. In particular, we show that for
each $k\geq 5$, it is NP-complete to check whether a planar bipartite graph of
maximum degree $k-2$ is graceful $k$-colorable. The complexity of checking
whether a planar graph is graceful 4-colorable remains open.
